security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation in markdown format. No executable code, scripts, network calls, filesystem access, or environment variable access. Pure reference documentation for coding standards.

content.value_statement: Portfolio Buddy 2 developers need consistent coding patterns to maintain code quality. This skill provides documented standards for React 19 components, TypeScript types, and project organization.
actual_capabilities: Defines React 19 component structure patterns with hooks
Specifies TypeScript standards including no `any` types
limitations: Reference documentation only, does not enforce standards
Specific to Portfolio Buddy 2 project structure
No automated linting or code checking

use_cases.title: New component creation
use_cases.description: Follow hook patterns and TypeScript standards when building new React components for the portfolio application.

use_cases.title: Review code contributions
use_cases.description: Verify pull requests meet documented standards for component size, types, and import organization.

use_cases.title: Technical debt reduction
use_cases.description: Use documented patterns to refactor oversized components like PortfolioSection.tsx into smaller pieces.

prompt_templates.title: Component pattern
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new React 19 component following the coding-standards skill. Use functional component with TypeScript, hooks at top level, useMemo for derived state, and useCallback for handlers.

prompt_templates.title: TypeScript types
prompt_templates.prompt: Define TypeScript interfaces for my data using the coding-standards skill. No any types, use strict null checks, and add JSDoc comments for complex functions.

prompt_templates.title: Refactor component
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me refactor this oversized component using patterns from coding-standards. Extract sub-components and move logic to custom hooks to stay under 200 lines.

prompt_templates.title: Import organization
prompt_templates.prompt: Organize my imports following the coding-standards skill: React libraries first, then internal hooks, then utils, then types.

best_practices: Always define TypeScript interfaces for data structures instead of using `any`
Keep components under 200 lines by extracting sub-components and custom hooks
Use React hooks at top level only with complete dependency arrays
anti_patterns: Using `any` type instead of proper TypeScript interfaces
Putting hooks inside conditionals or loops
Mixing global state libraries when plain React hooks are preferred

faq.question: What React features does this skill cover?
faq.answer: React 19 functional components, useState, useMemo, useCallback, useRef, and useEffect with proper dependency arrays.

faq.question: What TypeScript rules are enforced?
faq.answer: No `any` types, strict null checks, explicit interfaces for all data structures, and type inference when obvious.

faq.question: How does this integrate with Claude Code?
faq.answer: The skill provides documented patterns that Claude Code follows when generating or reviewing React 19 and TypeScript code.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only contains reference documentation. It does not access files, networks, or execute any code.

faq.question: Why is there a 200-line component limit?
faq.answer: Smaller components are easier to test, maintain, and debug. Larger components should be split into focused sub-components.

faq.question: How does this compare to eslint?
faq.answer: This skill documents architectural patterns and conventions. It complements linters by covering design and organization rules.
